												The game offers a very unique and interesting gameplay experience. It is well crafted and stable and no bugs have come to my knowing. It has some minor balance issues and design flaws. Overall i can recommend this game to people interested in RTS, who like to take on a challenge. This game is difficult. Stay away from it if you can not stand losing over and over again.The UI is thought out well and is very intuitive.Visuals are done nicely, no eyesore to be expected.The current standard price of about 20$ is more than justified.What is it about?To sum it up: The russian devs have built a hero management simulation on top of a classic RTS basis. It plays pretty fresh, and feels damn good.Basically, the units you build have minds on their own. There is no way to directly control them.They do hero stuff, they wander around in search of monsters and loot, they level up just like all heroes do and can become even better with shinier armor and bigger swords.Given some time, success and little dying they can develop from a wooden sword swinging wannabe knight to a professional murdering machine.They misjudge their chances and die in silly ways quite often, hindering the individual progress, cost you a lot of money and ultimately, cause you to fail the map. So, the chaotic bunch needs to be directed somehow. This is where the player jumps in. You can interact with various Spells on a smaller scale, but: What do heroes like ? Exactly, shiny things and money.Orders are handled by issuing quests. For example, there is a wolves den which annoys you. You can create a quest for your guys, by putting a reward on it. Heroes will take on that quest if they feel like its worth it, and soon, the wolves den will be history.The earned money then goes to that heroes purse and he will use it to buy Potions, enchant or buff himself in Guildhouses or buy new equipment if he doesn't die before he can spend it.The money spent by heroes comes back to your purse for the most part, so its a game of give and take. With the added risk of the hero dying, resulting in loss of that money with additional resurrection costs. (These can become very very costly with increasing levels)All Heroes will be acting selfishly on their own by default, giving little to no support to the "competing" heroes. Later on, you get the Option to group them into parties of up to four, making them work together to combine their abilities and increase in power by a lot. But also decreasing their response to quests significantly, which means, they'll consider themselves very elite and move out only for phat lewt.After every mission you get the chance to promote one hero to "Lord", saving him for reuse on the following maps. Which is a good but costly option. Some maps can only be won by utilizing this feature wisely. All other heroes are lost on map transition.This might sound all nice and cozy, and, yeah, when the basics are understood, the first few missions are not much of a problem.But the difficulty rises quite fast and brutal. The maps are very different from each other and you will need to come up with a solid build order and make it work over several attemps on each new mission again. You are under constant attack from the very beginning and can fail the mission very fast if attempting the wrong way. Gamechanging scripted events can cause sudden death even later on if handled wrong. It soon becomes a game of Chess, were you will need a clear plan of what to do when and perfect execution. The combination of this with the games occasional randomness can cause frustration at times. You've done nothing wrong, but still are wiped out brutally.This factor will multiply when later on, your opponents have leveling heroes as well, and failure will therefore be punished twice, by losing a lot of money, and having to face more powerful enemies. Resulting in very very frustrating moments.I'd say, the game, a couple of hours in, is a lot about trial and error and aims towards players with some dedication and will to win and has nothing to offer for casual players at all.For the more hardcore, there is a lot of fun to be had here.Having played the first part too, i really hope for a Majesty 3, the Game has come a long way already. I hope the developers see that too and give it another attempt. They could turn this already damn good, but underdog, game into a total blockbuster.

Update 1/2/17 A patch for the DLC has been released, and "approved" by Paradox! As that has been patched, this game is once again worth full value. Thank you to Nitrostriker for bringing this up, you can access the fix on the official paradox forums here: https://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/index.php?threads/majesty-2-collector-dlc-fix.983538/I know this game has been out for quite a while, but I'm mostly reviewing it to state it's still worth getting. I have about 300 more hours from a DRM free version, so however many hours I have on here is not accurate.If you're just curious about the "Collection" edition portion, it is worth the money based on the sheer amount of content added.For those who haven't played the first... (see below if you have played the first)It isn't important that you have played the first, as there isn't really any important information to transfer to the second. If you have ever wanted to play an RTS in which you don't have to deal with managing everything your units are doing, this is likely the game for you. It requires quick thinking (or average thinking at .2x speed) and some knowledge of each guild and building, but the main campaign eases you into the game at a pace that will teach you all you need to know. Many of the missions have unique side missions to make sure there's variation each time you play.Certain missions can be very difficult and will require you to be entirely precise in your decisions at the start (such as the mission in the King Maker expansion that sends a bunch of dragonlings at you near instantly). Clerics and Dwarven towers will quickly become your best friends.For those who have played the first...I've played the original majesty for likely 400+ hours, and have a lot of knowledge and memories of it to show for it. I see a lot of the negative reviews and comments are based solely upon the original "being better". I personally find this one to be much more than the first in almost every way. If you've played the first, you can expect to miss this... (cons) The tournament has been removed (my biggest negative) Heroes are harder to guide. No more naming of heroes. Mushrooms for poison have been turned into just an upgrade. Religious temples are now only able to be placed at set locations. A few other things.However, the additions make this one worth playing. (pros) Much easier UI to use. 3D graphics (which in my opinion are better). Many buildings combined (the library is now inherent in guilds) (may not be a pro to some) More guilds. A few extra skills, including skills gained at certain levels per class. More intuitive spell system. Many more missions. Ability to play as the enemies in a special campaign mode. Buildings don't completely catch fire when a rat bites it (who else was annoyed by this?) Heroes don't feel as squishy. (except for the mage. Expect them to still die every five seconds for their lower levels) Many more things.As for the difficulty...Yes, this game is 0 to 100 on certain missions, but all of them are completely possible. You will have to utilize the .2x speed button very frequently and will occassionally have to baby-sit your lower leveled powerful heroes with the heal spell. If all else fails, you can usually go back to using two cleric guilds at the start. Clerics are the toughest unit in the game as long as you can keep them together, as they're nearly infinitely powerful as long as some mana exists. Shortly after, you will want to get dwarves for both the unit and especially the tower. One tower alone is enough to kill a werewolf or a dragon, which can easily level an entire settlement early on. By placing a normal guard tower behind each dwarven tower, you effectively multiply the effectiveness of each tower by a decent bit.Krypta appears to be the most useful special hero for their sheer ability to stay alive while dealing heavily spread out damage with their minions.Also, do not forget to use inns. Having a few scattered on each side can save your heroes, since often times the guild is just far enough to have them killed when they retreat. Conclusion All in all, I feel this one is more full than the first. There are some noticeable changes, but for the most part, it's just something to get used to rather than miss intensely. This game is worth your time, and will immerse you faster than you might expect.

												I've never heard of Majesty 2 until the recent steam sale.  I'm a fan of real time and turn based strategy games and I must say that I've thoroughly enjoyed playing this game.  Just finished the original and kingmaker campaigns, it sure was fun.Don't think multiplayer works for this game but singleplayer is great.  In 64 hours of gameplay it has crashed on me only once.  So can't say it has many bugs.  The game is nicely polished and has good graphics for its age.  Haven't played Majesty 1, the graphics there are a bit of a turn off unfortunately, although many people think the gameplay of the older version is better.The campagn missions can be very difficult but they are beatable.  The increasing difficulty pushes you to explore the game more and read up on some strategies if you get really stuck.  When you are finally able to beat that difficult mission,  like the Rat King or The Avatar, then it feels really satisfying :)  With the Rat King mission I built a mage guild and then a wizard tower and kept activating it to protect my warriors until they levelled up.Economy is very important in this game, try to position your marketplace next to a trade post and then build a tower next to the market so the tax collector doesn't have very far to walk.   Group your economic buildings like the blacksmith and the potions bazaar next to that tower as well.There are a variety of strategies available with each mission.  You can create 'tanking' groups of 3 clerics + 1 dwarf.  Although groups don't seem to retreat as well as individual heroes.  Rangers are a good early to mid game option.  Some players build the Hall of Lords straight away.  Some of the cheap lords like levelled up Rogues and Rangers can be very useful in the early game and mid game, and that's usually the most crucial time.  A levelled up lord is not always the best option, it may be better to have lower level templars with good weapons so they are cheaper to buy.  And so on a so forth.  Sure the first game may have more options but Magesty 2 also offers alot of good gameplay so I think this game is sometimes rated unfairly, because it is a great game.  And if its on sale then its definitely worth it :)

												Some changes from Majesty 1, of which a lot of my childhood was spent playing.Improved AI: You can use this to cheese any map, as your peasants actually repair things in Majesty 2, hero AI is a lot better, with heroes making better choices. With new flags like guarding, you never have to worry about a skeleton ruining your entire economy because it got lucky and killed the caravan carrying much needed gold.Stronger guards: Palace and guard tower guards can now stand toe to toe with moderately strong enemies. Tax collectors seem much happier in this game. Arrows come with the guard tower, no need to spend gold researching them.Stronger classes in general: Mages and Rangers no longer die in 1-2 hits from rats anymore, clerics not only do actual damage, but they are even harder to kill than before. Mages do not have the extreme overkill capacity as they did in Majesty 1 if they survived to level 10, but they make up for it with better defenses / ai / and utility (freezing enemies). Elves have been buffed to the point of being useful unless you have to go with dwarves to fight early dragon onslaughts.Skeletons now reliably killable by level 1 Warriors: Skeletons are no longer magic resist / dodge gods and for the player, dwarves have taken their place for fighting strong magic monsters like dragons.Parties: You can now assign 4 heroes to a party. This allows you to tactically place your clerics where they need to be, and generally makes your heroes almost invulnerable.Enemy spawn rates increased: If you do not plan accordingly, you can have your low level heroes die to hordes of rats and skeletons while your better heroes are off doing the objective. Guard towers fix this problem easily, but I like to keep them to a minimum so that my heroes can level up and acquire gold for upgrades.More upgrades: Your casters now gain magic attack when they upgrade their weapons, and every class has a plethora of upgrades to purchase.I've read many reviews saying this game is too difficult. Without spoiling too much, learn the strengths and weaknesses of the heroes and learn how to set up and properly defend your economy, if your tax collectors die, you get no gold. Do not overlook palace upgrades. Remember your build orders so you can try something different if you fail.

												Seeing so many negative reviews its a shame I can't add my review to Majesty 2 since I own the Collection edition. So here will suffice. I rate this game 8.5/10 and I played the original Majesty too (rate:9/10). M2 is a sim  RTS+RPG game, Like RTS games you have create an economy, research, create armies and destroy the opponents. The sim part is because you don't control the units (caled heroes). You assign rewards to kill a monster or destroy a building and depending on the reward 0 or more of your heroes will go achieve your task (more money = more heroes). There are soe 5 different kinds of tasks you can assign to heroes. The heroes will buy themselves upgrades provided that you created the necessary buildings and invested  on the research (which cost gold). Placing the buildings is your task and its important. There are defense towers and many other kinds of buildings (15+). Heroes level as they gain more experience (RPG component). I love this whole concept of the Majesty series. Plus points:- Unique take on RTS- A variety of heroes: gnomes, archers, paladins, monks, necromancers (some 15+ types)- Rock-paper-scissors system. .- Varied gameplay in the campaign. - RPG element s great. You can check each of your heroes and see what spells/powers they have learned.- Game is well polished.Minus points:- Some of the latter missions are way too difficult. Basically, large number of monsters are thrown on your base before you even got the chance to set your economy. This frustrates the last 1/3 of the campaign. The first 2/3 are great. Its a shame. Maybe they should have add difficulty levels.- So there are cheats and the player is forced to either spend hours figuring out how to beat each of these later missions or use the cheats, which is a shame either way.- The concept is so amazing, one can't help feel that they could have designed a better campaign. One of the (hard) missions is to defeat two opposing kingdoms. It is incredibly cool as each of the opponents is using different armies. They could have thought other missions like that.

												I'm writing this review because It bothers me how little notoriety majesty getsMajesty 1 and Majesty 2 are both incredibly entertaining games that have value that long outlives their price point. Don't let my hours played fool you. I owned these games before steam was so common place and have likely sunk over 100 hours into Majesty 1 and at least 70 or so into Majesty 2.But what is the game like? Well, Majesty is an RTS game yes, but it is best described as being god of your own little fantasy MMORPG. Your units in the game act on their own free will, and you must tempt them to do deeds for the kingdom by setting up quests for them to accomplish in the game by way of bounties. It's an unusual system, that can occassionally be difficult to get the hang of, but once you do it feels natural.Like players in an MMO your units will level up, learn skills, & go to the shops and buy potions, weapons, armor, and whatever magic trinkets your market might have for sale. One of them might even get lucky and come across an extremely powerful weapon early in the game and go on to become a powerful lord of your land, valliantly defending against hordes of creatures that instantly wipe out your younger units, giving them breathing room to grow in power.I could ramble on for much longer about why I love this game, but I'll try to throw together a good old fashion pro's and cons list Pro's:-Beautiful fantasy art style and graphics. Every unit in the game looks great right from the start, but as they level up and purchase new weapons and armor their appearance changes in a satisfying and meaningful way. A level 1 warrior looks like nothing compared to a level 15 warrior.-Combat, while not being super involved on the part of the player, is always satsifying and fun to watch. As your units learn new skills either from training at a guild, or from leveling up, the way they fight changes. It's always neat to see the heroes fighting in new ways as the game goes on.-Intimidating monsters and quests that will challenge you. Because of the unusual method for defending your kingdom, it's not nearly so easy to defend in this game. Bunkering up with thousands of troops is not something you can do, so proper management is something you'll have to learn-Great silly voice acting from the royal advisor, and many good lines from your units. The dialog is just fun, that's all there really is to say about that.-Economics are easy to grasp, not spreadsheet material, but not♥♥♥♥♥♥easy either. You will run out of money, and you will suffer for it, but you wont need a college degree to figure out how to maintain your kingdom.Con's:-The game is hard, and if you've never played a majesty game before, then you're going to have a bit of a rough time starting out (Though for some this can easily be a pro)-It's frontloaded. Many missions are only hard at the start. By the time you establish your kingdom and have several powerful heroes wandering around, you'll easily take the rest of the mission by storm. (This is more of a problem with the vanilla campaign, and not so much with the DLC's)-Takes forever to unlock everything. You will have to complete over 70% of the in game missions to have every building and unit unlocked. This can be frustrating if your favorite unit or building is one of the very last to be unlocked. -AI is sometimes very stupid. Generally your units will do fine without your guidance and only need you to give them a quest for something majorly out of the way, like to raid an enemy keep, or defend a trading post. But sometimes a unit will choose to go to the store when a lich is about to blow their house to smithereens, and....well that is annoying.

On the one hand it is challenging and can be fun but on the other it can be unbelieveably frustrating with some level design that is so shockingly bad some of the levels are literally impossible unless you retry them 20+ times. The thing is most levels are tough but ultimately fair, if you play them correctly you win. However there are 2 levels very early on where you can literally lose before you have the chance to do anything. I'm not exagerrating with that, your builders can all be killed before you even construct your first building and you have no chance the rebuild. The dragon mission is like that too, sometimes the dragon comes and does nothing, other times it will come and kill all your builders AND destroy the buildings before you have built them. This is extremely stupid level design as you lose before you start. On top of that there is the extremely annoying bug that can cause the game to crash WHICH CORRUPTS THE SAVE! Yep, that one time you do survive and get a save, the game loses it. I cannot begin to describe how insanely idiotic and frustrating that is.You then have cases of heroes being stupid, a hero that is a high level will happily walk past a bunch of enemies tearing your base to pieces despite being more than capable of killing the lot with minimal effort. The paying money to influence hero actions is a good system but let down by the atrocious AI and the fact you can't refund a flag you placed if you change your mind, once the flag is placed the money is stuck to it permenantly rather than losing it upon the completion of the task.All this is a shame because the fundamental idea behind the game is interesting and it would be nice to see it remade. Having said that I cannot recommend this game just because the rat king and dragon missions (which you can't skip) are so SO♥♥♥♥♥♥poor and frustrating that you will be lucky to see the rest of the game without giving up and uninstalling. If those 2 missions were fixed to actually be fair then I'd recommend this as a fun game, all the other missions are acceptable.TL;DR 2 very poorly designed levels (ie impossible 90% of the time) and stupid AI ruin an otherwise interesting and challenging game. Avoid unless you have the patience of a saint.

												Real fun, most of the people hate the changes made in Majesty 2 but I really couldn't play the first one, not only because of the dated graphics but because the UI in majesty 2 is much much better. The "flag rewards" are all on one hud, so is the palace button, the buildings are organized in categories, etc. So what is Majesty 2? You essentially build your kingdom, recruit some heroes and give away some bounties. Heroes will decide if they want to goof around, do some adventuring on their own (very rare but possible), maybe do some shopping in the blacksmith you upgraded for them (and hey, if they spend money, you get it back with taxes) or just follow your "bounties". That's right, you don't control them, but you can tell them "Hey I'll pay you 300 gold for taking out that wolves' den". In Majesty 2 you can make parties too, seems strange that a King should concern itself with it, but hey, better me than a stupid AI, so you make your parties balanced and off you go for adventure.Haven't tried multiplayer yet, but I heard Internet servers are down and only LAN can be played, but anyway, I really like this game, there is enough rpg elements like abilities, levels, equips, stats for your heroes to love the customization and rts elements (more like city management rts but yeah). The last great part about this, which is highly personal, is that the game is in Ardania, the fantasy world and culture that I learned to love through Warlock - Master of the Arcane. All the bad rewievs didn't give me much hope for this game, but it's awesome, mods heavily recommended (they balance quite some things, I use Majesty 2 Reloaded).

Or do you research better spells, equipment, and potions for your heroes to use? Coming to forkroads like that  and then playing them out to see if you made the right choice are what gives the game so much character, if you can bear the 10 failed attempts beforehand where a boss teir dragon decided to attack your palace as soon as you loaded the level.

-Quick Review-Majesty 2 Collection is a real time strategy fantasy kingdom simulator, much like it's predecessor, Majesty. However Majesty 2 was developed by a new developer: 1C:Ino-Co. I don't have any other comments on the developer, I just wanted to highlight that this game has a different developer.Majesty 1 was developed by Paradox Interactive and released in 2000, Majesty 2 was developed by 1C:InoCo and released in Apr 19, 2011.


So Far, So good... 
A Screenshot of Majesty 2 Collection
By: Atratzu




-Detailed breakdown review-Story: *impersonates the Majesty Crier* (it's like a Sean Connery impersonation which George Ledoux does) "Welcome Majesty, it's been some time since we've last met, probably about 10 years. Many things have changed, some changes are good, some changes are bad, but change they have."Text doesn't really sell the impersionation, but one of the staples of the Majesty series was definitely the voice antics of George Ledoux, who voiced the Royal Advisor, Venn Fairweather.As the story goes, the realm has had years and years of peace, and suddenly something stirs up your old enemies again and you need to return to the battlefield to protect your people.Seeing as this is the Majesty 2 COLLECTION, you're also picking up some DLC with the core game; Majesty 2 (The core game), Kingmaker expansion , Battles of Ardania expansion , Monster Kingdom expansion. Naturally each expansion has it's own twist on the Majesty 2 Narrative. My personal favorite was the Monster Kingdom expansion because you find yourself making an alliance with your previous enemies. For once, *I* was the one summoning hordes of rats and goblins! Payback is sweat.


Party at the cemetery! (I just Rezzed everyone who died, so like 30 heroes) 
A Screenshot of Majesty 2 Collection
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: Not to re-invent the wheel, but if you want a better break down for the majesty game-play mechanics I highly suggest checking out my Majesty 1 review, I'll add a link at the end of this review. The quick explanation for anyone who hasn't played Majesty before: You set various flags with bounties which your hero's will either: Attack, explore, or defend. Depending on the flag you set.You also control the buildings you can construct, and can cast several spells, but only if you have the gold to lay the foundation for a building, or cast a spell. So there's a type of fantasy economy going on in the game. You build a marketplace which sells potions, Hero "mynameismud" walks into the marketplace you made, buys some potions, your tax collector walks by, picks up the taxes, returns to your castle, BAM now those coins are in youre treasury which you can use to upgrade your marketplace.There are different objectives and goals depending on the mission you're playing, as you progress you unlock more difficult missions which will have special conditions, sometimes you can only use a certain type of unit, other times you cannot construct something, other times you need to explore to discover the neccessary item/unit/guild/building.Contrasting Gameplay from Majesty 1 to Majesty 2: The gameplay at surface level doesn't seem to have changed very much from the days of Majesty 1... but the game definitely feels different. Somehow the only way I can describe the game is "....more difficult". which doesn't seem like a very fair criticism. Majesty 2 feels more fast paced, and less forgiving if you mess up. It also feels like you need to do what I loving call "over building" more then I did in Majesty 1.So basically my strategy has always been "Build as much as you can as early as possible, build enough hero's to keep your servants safe while they construct your money making buildings, then proceed to build the lowest costing guilds moving forward. So if I have 5 ranger guilds, I'll build some rogue guilds, and then warrior, then come back to ranger guilds when the price is lower then the other guilds.You never really felt like you had very much control in Majesty 1, so the fact that I feel like I don't have much control in Majesty 2 doesn't really phase me, but something just doesn't feel quite balanced in Majesty 2. It doesn't take away of my enjoyment for the game, but some people will definitely be put off by it.


This game can be just as Rage enducing as the first Majesty game. 
A Screenshot of Majesty 2 Collection
By: Atratzu




Conclusion: In conclusion... I'm biased for this game. I strongly suggest taking my opinion with a grain of salt when considering if you should play this game or not. I adored Majesty Gold Edition, even replaying the game I started playing and beating hard missions because I just adored the gameplay and had a knack for playing it.Majesty 2 is quite different though, the spirit of the game is kept pretty well, but the changes will rattle most avid Ardania fans. I can't recommend Majesty 2 to everyone like I can for Majesty 1 (Seriously, go try that game out if you haven't, it's so good!) But for those of you who might have an idea what you're getting into, this game could have been WAY worse, trust me, I played Lords of the Realm III recently.Anyway, thank you for taking the time to read my review for the Majesty 2 Collection. I hope to take this game on as a video review sometime, but until that time. 												On it's own merits, it's a unique game as far as strategy games go. It's not like most strategy games where you build a base and recruit a bunch of units, although it's similar. Instead you build guilds and hire heroes, who have their own unique AI patterns they follow and can't be directly controlled, only influenced by the player. Essentially this means the game is more of a simulation with the player playing the part of a quest giver for a typical RPG, with some town building aspects thrown in. You direct heroes with reward bounties for defending, attacking, or exploring whatever you put the bounty on. This costs you gold, which then goes into the heroes pockets, which they then use to buy equipment for further adventuring.This is a bit of a mixed bag. You rely on the AI to choose what to do, so your heroes might pick fights they can't win, run from fights they can win, ignore bounty targets with bounties that are too low, or put off buying better equipment to buy potions instead.It's arguable whether or not this game is better than the original, but it does have a lot of a quality of life improvements over the original. Heroes are always available to be brought back from the dead and the Hall of Lords can be used to recruit already leveled up heroes from past missions. Additionally there is a party system that allows you to have heroes group together. However hero AI is a bit simplified. Heroes don't wander off on their own as much as in the first game, and rarely have unique AI quirks such as the Ranger from the first game exploring on his own. This can make the game feel a bit less alive compared to the first game. The temple system  has been reworked as well. Now both temples and trading posts are built in specific spots on the map. This simplifies things, but also somewhat limits strategy in comparison to the first game.This version also comes with a lot of extra DLC missions. Including a neat and hilarious DLC campaign that has you using monster heroes instead of the typical human ones. Perhaps the funniest part of that DLC is the vampire tax collectors, who will actually attempt to defend themselves when attacked.

Strategy meets RPGA very nice blend of RTS, RPG and economic game. You are the ruler of Ardania, Fantasy Kingdom. You construct the guilds, economic buildings, research better weapons and shields. But you cannot control your heroes directly. They are controlled by setting rewards for specific goals like exploring a territory or killing a monster.There is a variety of missions and quests, some of which require attacking specific places or killing a monster which requires certain strategy. There is a huge choice of hero classes like warriors, wizards, rogues, clerics, paladins and nice selection of monsters with their dwellings including vampire crypts, elemental portals and wolf dens.The game has a unique style merging some qualities of "Heroes of Might and Magic", some of "Age of Empires" and others from RPG games. Many missions are really demanding. I needed to consult strategy guides to finish some of the levels, but even after reading a strategy guide you can find your unique tactics to defeating the boss. After 25 hours of playing I have finished this really enjoyable game.

												 The mission designs for this game are mind bogglingly aweful. After the initial maps (which are enjoyable), you are placed into scenarios where you will have multiple enemy spawn points within view of your keep and they WILL spawn monsters before you get your first building completed. You will attempt to get buildings erected but your pesants will get killed (slowing or stopping construction), or the buildings will be attacked (slowing down or destroying your construction and wasting your gold), your tax collectors will get killed as they make their rounds (delaying or halting your income), and your heroes will constantly get mobbed (forcing them to hide in the guild hall for healing and be ineffective, or they'll die), dead heroes cause a graveyard to spawn nearby (which also spawns more monsters), etc...Administrative style games (where you do not have direct control of your units) requre a build up phase to allow a player to prepare for threats. Especially because a player is unable to directly send the heroes to address threats at a moments notice. Using the flags and bounty system to incentivize your heroes takes money from your coffers and only works if you make the bounty large enough to grab their attention. Setting bounties, of course, hinders your ability to build essential infrastructure. The issues that this game has is not a matter of lack of player skill. There is very poor balancing in the game's economy and combat systems. There are some well concieved scenarios in the first third of the game where you are under constant pressure and the challenge is intense and enjoyable. However, in other scenarios where the waves of enemies constantly intensify, your base's capabilities will palteau and eventually crumble, but the enemy will not plateau. When this is combined with a scenario that causes you to constantly struggle to build and keep two or three buildings standing, you end up with a frustrating and disappointing experience.Unfortunately, it takes more than two hours to find this out, so a refund is off the table. My time with Magesty 2 makes me wonder if the devs actually had the game playtested it to understand exactly what kind of play experience they were actually creating. The genere is one of my favorites, the gameplay can be at times enjoyable, but there is too much in this game that is not enjoyable. I recommend not buying this one.

												Let me start by saying I own the original majesty and expansion on disk and have played it for years.  So I will be comparing it  to M 1.The two games are very similar.  Almost identical on the surface.   However, M1 is very hard to play on modern machines.1. The early game is a bit of a struggle financially as your income is severly limited until you are able to get trading posts up and running without losing them.  In M1 you could place a trading post anywhere on the map outside a limited radius from your marketplace.  In M2 you are restricted to only a few preset locations for trading posts, but the upgrade for them is a weak turret able to defend from weaker foes.  Your progress in the game is entirely limited and artificially paced by your gold income, so it can be a little frustrating in the early game.2. Guilds are limited now to 3 heroes while in M1 you had up to 4. The way M2 is set up, the number of heroes you have doesnt have much impact on your income like it did in M1.3. Your marketplace has a set income per level and you can only have 1 marketplace, period. M1 allowed you to build many marketplaces and use the marketday feature to get more money to help you in the early game.  M2 controls the pace of your economic development rather harshly IMO.  It makes one of the campaign scenarios almost impossible that depends entirely on saving up a set amount of gold in a rather short time.  Gold that you need to defend your settlement from the constant onslaught of dragons and elementals from day one.  I tried that scenario a number of times now and still havent managed to save up the required gold(35,000) in the time limit. Im constantly having to hire or ressurect new heroes and upgrading everything so they can survive against dragons and elementals.  I think its possible to win, but I havent done so yet.  So anyway... the economy design in M2 is rather weak IMO.4. They have combined the graveyard with the mausoleum from M1.  Making a graveyard that now produces enemy skeletons on your settlement and you can also pay to resurrect your heros from it.  You do not have to buy a graveyard, it just appears at a random location by your settlement once you have had a hero die.  It takes up alot more space than the M1 graveyard though and that can cause problems when trying to organize your settlement.5. Guard towers are nearly invincible in M2 compared to M1.  However, when you upgrade your tower, your tower guard doesnt get stronger, which was a little disappointing to me.  A tower is cheap and can handle all but the strongest creatures, but also a large number of medium sized creatures can overwhelm a tower without hero help.  The point is, they are strong and I surround my castle with them right away at the start of a game.  I think they are a little too strong, and the guards a little too weak.6. The Inn.  M1 inn were a good source of steady income.  They produced gold regularly just like the peasant huts but a little more and heroes loved to hang out at the inns which also generated more gold when they did.  The Inn in M2 are pretty useless.  They dont generate gold and you can use them to create hero parties up to 4 members after upgrading it.  I think they do get some gold from heroes that visit the inn, but it seems that heroes prefer to run home instead of to the closest Inn.  To me the hero groups seem rather pointless, plus it costs you 500 gold just to form the group.  Overall the Inn isnt worth the investment.7. Temples.  Temples have almost become a moot point in M2.  You cant build one until you have upgraded lvl 3 castle and guilds, AND they cost a fortune to build, AND you can only build them on preset spots on the map whihc often are far from your settlement, AND you cna only hire 2 temple heroes or for an exorbant price you can convert an existing hero to a temple hero.  By the time you are able to get a temple, your heroes are already powerful, have everything, and most of the map will be cleared out.  There literally no reason to get a temple except that its something to spend your late game gold on.  In M1 you only needed a lvl 2 castle to build most temples and then you could hire all the cool temple heroes and get the spells relatively early in the game and enjoy them.  M2 has botched up temples IMO.8. Heroes Inventory space.  Too small.  They get 2 slots for a weapon and armor, and 4 slots for everything else.  Well guess what....   **** the magic bazaar and the 7 different potions available. Maybe its more than 7.  Im not sure since I havent finished the campaign and there are blank slots in the stores.  I will build a magic bazaar because it generates automatic income, but I do not research any potions.  Your heroes have limited inventory space and they need that space for the 2 magical protections at the market, a weapon and armor, healing and mana potions.  There is no room for anything from the magic bazaar.  They ****** up with that.  I dont recall how much inv space heroes had in M1, but I dont recall there being any issue.9. The Hall of Heroes.  Its a nice touch for the campaign, to be able to select a hero that you can hire again in the next scenario.  However...  by the time you can afford to build it and hire those old heroes, your new heroes will have caught up to them in levels and power so its rather pointless.  Better to just build another guild. Plus, what use is it in a multiplayer game?  Or even a custom game(if there is custom games... I havent checked)As far as I can tell... none.10. Scouting missions.  I dont recall from M1, but in M2 it seems only a ranger or elf.. and maybe a rogue will take an exploration mission.  I played one scenario and didnt have any of those 3 guilds and I would place exploration flags out, and not a single hero would do them, no matter how much money I put on them.  That annoyed me.11. The heroes are generally strong at low lvls compared to M1.  In M1 you would have heroes dying all the time at low levels with no equipment.  It made sense.  But was easy enough to just hire a replacement.  In M2 the heroes at low lvl are pretty strong.  Unless of course the incoming foes were high lvl.  They just run away.  Depending on the difficulty, they almost never die.  Warriors get tons of health, and clerics heal themselves... alot.  Plus, each guild can research special attacks, so not only are they tougher, but they hit really hard late game, even without upgraded weapons and armor.  Wait til you hire dwarves.  They are REALLY powerful. A lvl 1 dwarf is the equal of a lvl 10 warrior, at least.12. Something else about the dwarves.  They use hammers.  Or battleaxes.  I cant tell.  But there are no axes or hammers for sale in the blacksmith.  Only blades.  The dwarf can buy the blades and it counts as an upgrade for their hammers, or whatever.  A design flaw?  A cut corner?  Whatever it is, its sloppy and it breaks the immersion factor.13. The game runs really well, even on high settings with all the bells and whistles.  But, its still just as cartoony as M1.Summary.  It seems they tried to cut a few corners here and there, maybe even tried to innovate a little bit from M1, but overall I think they screwed up what they tried to change from M1.  From the restricted economy, which is no fun, to the limited hero inventory and the preset building locations which limits the building freedom you had with M1, and the pointless endgame buildings.There are no custom games in this.  M1 had complete customization, this does not.  Overall its not a terrible game, but it has more than enough shortcomings that I cannot recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												This is a great game that takes a departure from stnadard RTS games in that you don't have direct control over your units. You start each level with a castle and you have to build various guilds and economic structures in order to grow your kingdom. You decide which buildings to build, which things to upgrade, and how many units to train. The only resource is money, and it is handled either throw your own economy of units buying things at the marketplace to improve their stats, or by building trading posts. Units will interact with buildings by buying better armor, potions, etc. and begin to level up as they face off against creatures that attack you kindgdom. You can manipulate your heroes by assigning reward flags to targets, setting explore flags, or setting defend flags. Each level is designed with a particular objective (kill a target, gather enough gold, defend for x number of days, etc)There is lots of unit variety, from rogues, to archers, mages, warriors, and then high level units which have powerful abilities later on in the game. There are also lots of things to upgrade, and many unit combination to explore once you can build inns and form parties. Leveling your units is also satisfying as they learn powerful skills and maul their enemies in the most impressive and satisfying ways. This game is incredibly addicting once you get the hang of it, and missions easily span hours at a time. Graphically the game holds up great and things animate and look reasonably well. There is some nice humour thrown in for good measure with your advisor having a rather amusing sean-connory-like voice. Also your units say random things as they go about their business in your kingdom, so this game has quite a bit of charm. However, I will say that there isn't much of a story, but the mission scenarios feel varied enough with you having to fight all sorts of mystical creatures in intereting ways.  As far as difficulty, about half way through the game it skyrockets. The premise of the game is to manage to build a starting kingdom with limited resources that can fend off attackers. Once you get comfortable and money starts rolling in you, you can amass a grand army and plow pretty much anything. The issue is that you have to become very clever with where you put guard towers, and were you position your marketplace/guilds. Especially in the later missions, older strategies won't work and you'll have to do a lot of trial and error to figure things out, ie. it almost becomes a puzzle game. This game is definitely not for the faint of heart and it gets really HARD. Reading guides online is sometimes the only way to progress (it's totally frustrating, but also totally worth it once you figure things out). In my case, I couldn't get passed only 2 missions, so I used a hack to get extra money at the start, which is another option to make certain missions more enjoyable. This collection comes with 4 games. The original majesty 2, 2 expansions which just add extra missions, and then the Monster Kingdom. The first 2 expansions ramp up the difficulty even more and I recommend staying away from them unless you really like this game. The last expansion swaps your human-like kingdom for a monster-kingom. The difficulty is much better balanced and makes for a better expeience. In sum, I have put in 25 hours over the course of 3 days into this game (it is hellishly addicting once you get going). In total there is probably 50+ hours packed into this package. I can heartily recommend giving this game a go, because it's an experience unlike any you've ever had. Just be prepared for the difficulty spike (so use those internets to your advantage).

												Alright, here is my review after putting in half a day's worth of time in to this game. Oh, and before I go any further, no, I did not complete the campaign, I'll get to why in a moment. So, without further delay, here is my breakdown of this game.First of all, this game is for masochists, whether you got an unnoficial "balancing mod" or not. This is hands down the most frustrating misuse of a fantastic idea I've ever seen. The idea is pretty great, a fantasy sim city builder that tasks you with managing the kingdom by building and providing incentives for things to get done, all while your heroes do their "best" to rise in level and maybe usefullness. There's also some great voicing, at least on your side, and some pretty cool ideas that actually pan out (such as creating parties), but that's about it. Now, for the long list of absolutely terrible crap that will continue to make your gaming experience hell. To start with, difficulty, there isn't any way to control this as the game goes from novice to advanced after two missions (read easy to holy hell wtf happened to my town?!) A lot of your completed missions thereafter are based off of luck rather than skill due to enemy spawns and constant zerg-like-rushing. Oh, did I forget to mention that? Yeah, there is absolutely zero room whatsoever for flexible strategy. Thanks to that weird developer minset you'll find that some heroes are just plain worthless, causing you to only waste your gold on their buildings for upgrades. Oh, speaking of gold, enemies don't rely on any kind of resource for whatever unholy reason, and can continue to pump wave after wave at you until you take care of their spawns. This is usually only mildly irratible however, on some later missions, you'll find yourself constantly under pressure or on the brink of ruin merely two or so minutes into a level. So if you like rushing your missions by pumping out the right heroes from the get go without actually taking the time to enjoy the game (read play for more than five minutes per mission) then this is the game for you. If you like to take your time to actually enjoy your purchase, forget this game, seriously just forget it.So, if you've actually made it this far in my review and still wish to purchase this game AND don't consider yourself a masochist, I strongly recommend you dowload an unoffical balance mod. The one I used came from this site: "https://esatire.wordpress.com/2012/07/09/majesty-2-is-actually-fun-now-thanks-to-modding/" and it helped me somehow manage to enjoy myself up until a particularly frustrating mission called "Royal Feat". Honestly if game developers design it so that you have to play a fantasy/sim builder/RTS as a juiced up version of Starcraft from zerg-rush hell then they're doing something incredibly, moronically, wrong.I get way less stress playing the Ikko Ikki on Total War: Shogun 2. 												This is of course a sequel to Majesty: The Fantasy Kingdom Sim, just a collection with all the DLC (think expansion packs, not just small additions though there are a few). I recommend picking the original up if you can handle dated graphics, the gold edition is available on Steam as well but that's not what this review is for.Like the original game you play as the King of Ardania, who with your trusty comedic aide/advisor you build a fairly simplistic kingdom of a market, blacksmith, guardhouses and various guilds to train Heroes. Heroes are the key to this game as they are the characters that will fight your battles and you have the most influence over. Influence is the best word because you cannot directly command them to do anything, just merely suggest they do some tasks by setting bounties (attack, explore, defend) as well as a fear flag which while it isn't a bountie in the true sense, they work on the same mechanics.The campaign chronicles the journey to become the undisputed King of Ardania, as time progressed from the first king (from the first game) each king has tried to secure their place in history with grander feats of bravery. Lets just say the last king didn't do so well and you should watch the opening cinematic to see the bravery your forebearers had. The campaign is missioned based and you generally need to complete each mission to progress to the next ones, they generally unlock one or two missions at the same time and for replay value the tutorial is completely optional. Be warned, it does start simple but you do get a large difficulty spike later.I recommend a Majesty game to anyone who is remotely interested in the premise of the game, this is a worthy sequel but the changes made sort of balance out the improvements made to make it equivalent to the original. The biggest difference from the original (for me) is most heroes will not respond to your bounties quickly unless you put some real money on them, not necessarily a bad thing because it does seem you get more gold income but it can be slightly annoying if you're used to the original. If you want this as an updated version of Majesty you won't be dissapointed, though you may find yourself wanting a bit more.
